BNF Mets/Alto importer¶

This importer extends the generic Mets/Alto importer, and it was developed to handle OCR newspaper data provided by the BNF.

Custom classes¶

class text_importer.importers.bnf.classes.BnfNewspaperIssue(issue_dir: impresso_commons.path.path_fs.IssueDirectory)¶

Class representing an issue in BNF data. All functions defined in this child class are specific to parsing BNF Mets/Alto format

xml¶

Returns a BeautifulSoup object with Mets XML file of the issue.

class text_importer.importers.bnf.classes.BnfNewspaperPage(_id: str, n: int, filename: str, basedir: str)¶

Class representing a page in BNF data.

xml¶

Redefined as for some issues, the pages are in gz format

Detect functions¶

text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.BnfIssueDir¶

A light-weight data structure to represent a newspaper issue.

This named tuple contains basic metadata about a newspaper issue. They can then be used to locate the relevant data in the filesystem or to create canonical identifiers for the issue and its pages.

Note

In case of newspaper published multiple times per day, a lowercase letter is used to indicate the edition number: ‘a’ for the first, ‘b’ for the second, etc.

Parameters:
  • journal (str) – Newspaper ID
  • date (datetime.date) – Publication date
  • edition (str) – Edition of the newspaper issue (‘a’, ‘b’, ‘c’, etc.)
  • path (str) – Path to the archive containing OCR and OLR data
  • rights (str) – Access rights on the data (open, closed, etc.)
 
>>> from datetime import date
>>> i = BnfIssueDir(journal='Marie-Claire', date=datetime.date(1938, 3, 11), edition='a', path='./BNF/files/4701034.zip', rights='open_public')

alias of text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.IssueDirectory

text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.DATE_SEPARATORS = ['/', '-']¶

In BNF data, dates can be given in two different formats (separated with - or /). Also, an issue can have two dates, separated by either - or /

text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.detect_issues(base_dir: str, access_rights: str = None)¶

Detects BNF issues to import within the filesystem

This function the directory structure used by BNF (one subdir by journal)

Parameters:
  • base_dir (str) – Path to the base directory of newspaper data.
  • access_rights (str) – Not used for this imported, but argument is kept for normality
Returns:

List of BnfIssueDir instances, to be imported.
text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.dir2issue(issue_path: str, access_rights_dict: dict) → text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.IssueDirectory¶

Creates a BnfIssueDir object from an archive path

Note

This function is called internally by detect_issues

Parameters:
  • issue_path (str) – The path of the issue within the archive
  • access_rights_dict (dict) –
Returns:

New BnfIssueDir object
text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.select_issues(base_dir: str, config: dict, access_rights: str) → Optional[List[text_importer.importers.bnf.detect.IssueDirectory]]¶

Detect selectively newspaper issues to import.

The behavior is very similar to detect_issues() with the only difference that config specifies some rules to filter the data to import. See this section for further details on how to configure filtering.

Parameters:
  • base_dir (str) – Path to the base directory of newspaper data.
  • config (dict) – Config dictionary for filtering.
  • access_rights (str) – Not used for this imported, but argument is kept for normality
Returns:

List of BnfIssueDir instances, to be imported.

Helper methods¶

Set of helper functions for BNF importer

text_importer.importers.bnf.helpers.SECTION = 'section'¶

Content types as defined in BNF Mets flavour. These are the ones we are interested in parsing. The SECTION type should be flattened, and should not be part of content items, but it is needed to parse what’s

inside.
text_importer.importers.bnf.helpers.add_div(_dict: dict, _type: str, div_id: str, label: str) → dict¶

Adds a div item to the given dictionary (sorted by type). The types should be in BNF_CONTENT_TYPES or SECTION

Parameters:
  • _dict (dict) – The dictionary where to add the div
  • _type (str) – The type of the div
  • div_id (str) – The div ID
  • label (str) – The label of the div
Returns:

The updated dictionary
text_importer.importers.bnf.helpers.get_dates(date_string: str, separators: List[str]) → List[Optional[str]]¶

Assumes that the given date string represents exactly 2 dates. Tries to separate them using the given separators, and returns when it has found two dates.

If the function does not find exactly two dates, it returns None

Parameters:
  • date_string (str) – The date string
  • separators (list[str]) – The list of potential separators
Returns:
text_importer.importers.bnf.helpers.get_journal_name(archive_path)¶

Returns the Journal name from the path of the issue. It assumes the journal name is one directory above the issue

Returns:
